metadata.title: Synthesis of HMF from fructose using Purolite<ce:sup loc=post>®</ce:sup> strong acid catalyst: Comparison between BTR and PBR reactor type for kinetics data acquisition

Graphical abstract 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furfural (HMF) is an important furanic compound that can be obtained from renewable raw materials. HMF has wide application in the industry, acting as an intermediate in the production of fine chemicals, polymer, biofuels, and pharmaceuticals. In this research, HMF was obtained from the catalytic fructose dehydration. Purolite® SGC650H, a gel-type strongly acidic resin, was applied as a catalyst using dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) as a solvent. All experiments were carried out in a batch reactor (BTR) and a continuous packed bed reactor (PBR). The reactor performance data showed that increase in temperature resulted in higher HMF yield. In contrast, the higher the fructose concentration, the lower the HMF conversion. The HMF production rates in the PBR were higher because of the concentration of the catalyst. The rate constants were calculated by means of a pseudo-first-order reaction model, and the Arrhenius kinetic parameters obtained changed with regards to the reactants concentrations. The kinetic parameters displayed linear correlation in the Cremer-Constable diagram, which means that the system was under a kinetic compensation effect (KCE); therefore, the model was not suitable to represent the reaction. Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LHHW) models for rate equation were also tested. However all of them failed to adjust to the data, and thus a rate law was not determined. Due to the observed KCE, it was believed that there is at least a set of parallel dehydration reactions initiated from the different fructose isomers which has an influence on kinetic parameters. Keywords 5-Hydroxymethyl-2-furfural Fructose dehydration Heterogeneous catalysis Batch reactor Continuous reactor 1 Introduction The increase in demand for fossil fuels, the forecasts for their supplies depletion, the rise in their extraction costs as well as growing concern about environmental issues are the main factors necessary in the search for technologies to produce energy and chemical inputs, in order to reduce the dependence on these non-renewable resources [1,2]. 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furfural (HMF) is an essential building block due to its industrial potential to produce biofuels, solvents (2,5-dimethylfuran, γ-valerolactone), drugs, resins or monomers for biopolymers (2,5-furan dicarboxylic acid) and other platform substances (levulinic acid) [3]. Due to its potential as a chemical platform, the synthesis of HMF with high yield and selectivity is desirable. The general route of saccharide dehydration follows the removal of up to three molecules of water in an aqueous or organic medium through acid catalysis. However, the acid catalysis also fosters the following, hydrolysis, generating the levulinic and formic acids, or even the formation of condensation by-products, oligomerization, and polymerization, such as soluble polymers and insoluble humins (Fig. 1 ). These can be formed from the reaction between the reagent and products from the dehydration (HMF), which contribute to decreasing the selectivity of HMF [4,34]. Glucose as a substrate presents lower productive efficiency when compared to fructose during the formation of HMF [5,44]. This occurs due to the stability of the cyclical structure which is made up of six atoms in glucose, namely pyranose, when compared to the cycle of five atoms in fructose (furanose), which results in a lower degree of enolization responsible for the generation of HMF [6,7]. Therefore, the initial isomerization from glucose to fructose is an important reaction to be considered to improve the generation of HMF, and it occurs using Lewis acids (such as ZnCl2, AlCl3 [45,46] and BF3) as catalysts, while Brönsted acids (e.g., niobium pentoxide and phosphate) are responsible for the reaction of fructose dehydration [8,9]. In the cases when disaccharides and polysaccharides are used (e.g., sucrose, inulin, and cellulose) as raw materials, it is necessary to carry out an initial depolymerization through hydrolysis [10,11]. The main catalysts used are mineral acids, organic acids, ionic liquids, Lewis acids, metallic chlorides, oxides, phosphates, heteropoly acid compounds, zeolites, mesoporous solids and ion exchange resins [9]. The acid catalysis performed to obtain HMF may be carried out with homogeneous [32,37,38] and heterogeneous [36,39–43] catalysts. Nonetheless, heterogeneous catalysts present higher selectivities when compared to homogeneous ones, in addition to being less toxic, less corrosive, and presenting an easier separation, which enables the recycling and adaptation for large-scale continuous systems. Resins are made up of reticulated polystyrene containing sulfonic groups and are usually presented in the form of a gel. They are insoluble and are not attacked by solvents; however, they may expand and swell due to the elasticity of the matrix, which makes them different from the rigid structure of zeolites. The catalytic reaction of resins in liquid mediums is analogous to the homogeneous catalysis by dissolved electrolytes, and the advantages of its use are the separation by decantation or filtration and the possibility of continuous operation in columns [13]. Another polymeric heterogeneous catalyst has been studied such as polyaniline [43], or its sulfonated form [42] or polymers designed to mimic the co-catalyst effect of DMSO [40]. According to Kuster [6], by using ionic exchange resins as catalysts, the formation of insoluble humins must be avoided. To that end, the use of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) is recommended with a solvent or biphasic system for the continuous extraction of HMF from the reaction medium. The solvent is a determining factor for the conversion reaction from fructose to HMF, as it promotes fluidity and contact between the reagent and the catalyst. In choosing the choice of the reaction medium, the solvation properties must be carefully considered because it is economically recommended to work with high concentrations of the solute, which may increase the probability of humin formation, depending on the solvent [6]. The commonly applied solvents are water, methanol, DMSO, organic/aqueous mixtures, ionic liquids and biphasic systems [14]. The use of an aqueous solvent is most advantageous from an economic point of view – because it is less toxic and non-inflammable; however, most solid acids lose their catalytic activity and stability in an aqueous medium [6]. Additionally, anhydrous solvents such as DMSO and ionic liquids foster higher yields and lower formations of humins and products from hydrolysis, such as formic and levulinic acids [4]. Regardless of the type of catalyst or solvent used, most of the studies previously carried out were carried out in batch type reactors [3–5,8,9,12,14,15,18–21,27,28,30–33,36–44]. The use of continuous reactors was less explored [10,47,48]. One study carried out with both batch and continuous reactors [11] was performed with a didactic purpose. This study presents the results of a research comparing two reactor systems; batch reactor (BTR) and a continuous packed bed reactor (PBR), for the reaction of fructose dehydration to form HMF using a strongly acidic resin as catalyst and DMSO as a solvent. The objective of the study was to evaluate the kinetics of the reaction that fit the data and explain the mechanism and the performance of the reactors. 2 Experimental design d-Fructose was used as a reagent and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) was used as a solvent in this study. Both chemicals were purchased from Synth®. The strong acid cationic gel resin obtained from Purolite®, SGC650H, which is a Brönsted acid type (characteristics presented in Table 1 ) was used as a catalyst. Nitrogen from Air Liquide® was used for the inertization of the reaction medium. Acetonitrile (HPLC level) and glacial acetic acid (100%) from Merck® were used in the characterization by HPLC. HMF (99%) was obtained from Sigma Aldrich® to prepare the patterns and calibration curve. 2.1 Batch reaction Based on the methodology applied by Kimura et al. [15], fructose, DMSO (300 mL) and SGC650H resin (30 g) were added to a stainless-steel Parr autoclave reactor with capacity for 1 L (Fig. 2 ). The autoclave was equipped with a built-in heater, a stirrer adjusted for 700 rpm and a sampling system equipped with a filter (steel screen) to prevent the loss of the catalyst. After its proper closure, the reactor was cleansed with nitrogen to remove the oxygen from its interior. Afterward, the reactor was pressurized at 10 psig with nitrogen in order to facilitate subsequent samples, and the heating up to the desired temperature was conducted, which was maintained by the controller. The heating time of the tests varied from 20 to 45 min until the reaction medium reached the pre-defined temperature. At that stage, it was considered as the initial reaction time. Ten-milliliter (10 mL) samples were removed in the course of the reaction and cooled for further analysis. 2.2 Continuous reaction The continuous tests were carried out in a stainless-steel tube prepared to behave like a Packed Bed Reactor. The tube was 82 mm long, with an external diameter of ½″ and an internal diameter of 10 mm into the reactor. 5.3 g of the raw SGC650H resin was placed inside the reactor by the use of steel screens and glass wool on the edges of the tube (Fig. 3 ). It was submerged in an oil bath to control the desired temperature, and the raw solvent was initially pumped into the reactor at 1 mL/min for approximately 20 min. After the change for the solution of fructose feed, the beginning of each test was considered after approximately three residence times to ensure that the system was steady. The pump was deactivated after completing each sampling process, and its outflow was reset to start another test condition, using the same temperature of reaction and feed concentration, but with a different flow rate. After experimenting with each sample using different flow rate, the entire system together with the pump and raw solvent was cleaned up again before moving on the next experiment. The same procedure was carried out while varying the parameters regarding temperature and feed solution concentration. Due to the high boiling temperature of the DMSO, its use as a solvent allowed us to carry out tests at atmospheric pressure in a continuous reactor at temperatures ranging from 90 °C to 110 °C. 2.3 Products characterization The samples were diluted in deionized water with factors varying from 1 to 400, for the characterization of HMF. The HPLC column was a Shim-pack CLC-ODS (M)® reversed-phase column operating at 30 °C, binary eluent with a flow rate at 1.2 mL/min of acetonitrile and acetic acid 1% (m/m) in the ratio of 20:80 and UV–vis detector at 266 nm at 40 °C. The concentration of HMF was based on the calibration curve. Thus, their yield and conversion were defined as: (1) Y ( % ) = ( H M F m o l a r c o n c e n t r a t i o n ) ( F r u c t o s e m o l a r c o n c e n t r a t i o n f e e d ) * 100 (2) X ( % ) = ( 1 − ( F r u c t o s e m o l a r c o n c e n t r a t i o n ) ( F r u c t o s e m o l a r c o n c e n t r a t i o n f e e d ) ) * 100 2.4 Kinetic modeling In this calculation method, a similar approach to Lee & Wu [31] was used, who also considered the high selectivity of the transformation of fructose to HMF using DMSO as a solvent in the presence of sulfonic Brönsted acid catalysts [21]. The reaction was initially considered as pseudo-first-order-homogeneous and integrating the equation regarding the conversion. The rate law of the reaction is defined by Eq. (3) (3) r F = − k · C F n In which rF represents the index of the fructose reaction; k, the rate constant; CF , the molar concentration of fructose in mol/L and n, the reaction order (n = 1). The molar balances of the limiting reagent in a BTR considering a perfect mixture and in a PRF are, respectively: (4) d N F d t = r F · V (5) F F 0 · d X d V = − r F In which NF represents the molar quantity of the limiting reagent (in this case, fructose) at the time t of the reaction; V, the reactional volume; FF0 , the initial molar outflow of the limiting reagent in mol/h; and X, the reagent conversion. Combining the rate laws with the molar balances, we can find three first-class ordinary differential equations which, when integrated, respectively result in: (6) − ln ( 1 − X ) = k · t (7) − ln ( 1 − X ) = k · τ In which τ means the average residence time or stay at the continuous reactor, taking the volumetric outflow v0 constant throughout the reactor’s volume, being defined by τ = V/v0 . In the calculation of initial rates [16], the variances for high residence times in the reactor which did not adjust to the model was ignored and only the initial data that presented linear trend estimation was considered, in a way that the inclination at the initial stage corresponds to the kinetical constant k. In this study, this inclination was calculated by the derivation of the equation of the linear trend estimation at the initial stage (t = 0 h or τ = 0 min). As the system is heterogeneous, the molar balances and rate law can be written based on the catalyst’s mass (W), in a way that the reaction’s rates and rate constants are correlated by the concentration of the catalyst according to: (8) r F = r F ′ · C c a t (9) k = k ′ · C c a t in which r′ F and k′ are based on the dry catalyst’s mass; Ccat is the catalyst’s concentration which, in the BTR, was calculated at each point of the sample, correcting the reactor’s volume after the sampling rate without a catalyst. It was suppose that the density of the reaction medium is approximately equal to the solvent’s (DMSO) and that the solutes do not significantly interfere in this parameter. In order to simplify the calculations of the differential equations for the BTR, it was proposed that the reactional volume be constant and that the catalyst’s concentration increase along the time, similarly to a semi-batch reactor with catalyst feeding flow. With the values of the kinetic constants, it was possible to calculate the reaction’s activation energy (EA ) through the Arrhenius equation: (10) k ' = k 0 ' · exp ( − E A R · T ) in which k0′ is the pre-exponential constant; T, the reaction’s absolute temperature; and R, the universal constant of ideal gases (83,145 J/mol K−1). The comparisons of the rate equations and the equation obtained through the full method of each type of reactor are presented in Table 2 , in which the ratio PBR:BTR was obtained at stages with the same fructose conversion and concentration (in both reactors), i.e., X BTR = X PBR and CF BTR = CF PBR. 2.4.1 Iterative method One of the disadvantages of using the Parr reactor was the temperature variation during the heating until it reached reaction temperature, which hampered the kinetic analysis. For this reason, an iterative optimization method was used to calculate the Arrhenius parameters, applying the ones obtained through the full method as an initial value. Still considering a pseudo-first-order homogeneous reaction, the reaction rate in which the variables were a function of time was: (11) r F ( t ) = d C F ( t ) d t = − k ′ ( t ) · C c a t ( t ) · C F ( t ) The reagent’s concentration was only known in the reactor’s feed, in a way that it was simulated on an electronic spreadsheet by optimization, stipulating a consistent Δt along the reaction. (12) ( C F ) t + Δ t = ( C F ) t − ( k t ′ ) t · ( C c a t ) t · ( C F ) t · Δ t The values obtained (Ea and k0′ ) were adjusted to the experimental data through the method of the least squares, in which the sum of the deviations to the power of two is minimized through the Solver tool from Excel® by the Non-linear GRG method when varying the parameters studied. 2.4.2 LHHW method The heterogeneous kinetic catalysis uses the same concentration and temperature principles; however, other factors are also essential and must be added to the equation, such as the formation of a complex on the surface and its formation rates. Following the described methodology elsewhere [17], the determination of the rate equation by the Langmuir-Hinshelwood & Hougen-Watson (LHHW) approach may be carried out by obtaining data under conditions in which diffusion does not limit the reaction. Moreover, by observing the behavior of the initial reaction rate graph in function of the reagent’s initial concentration, which may show indications regarding the limiting stage of the reaction: adsorption, desorption or reaction on the surface. The development of a rate law for the global reaction involves a selection of a mechanism that describes each stage of the reaction, which rate laws are treated as elementary. Considering that the one from these steps is limiting, the concentrations of the adsorbed species may be obtained by manipulating the expressions of the non-limiting stages. Combining them with the expression of the limiting stage and the balance of sites on the catalyst’s surface, a possible rate equation for the global reaction can be obtained. Several kinetic equations may be found, depending on the accepted hypothesis, but always following: (13) ( reaction rate ) = ( kinetic term ) · ( driving force or balance shift ) ( adsorption term ) If the rate laws linearly adjust the experimental data, the constants may be determined through multiple linear regression. Statistical interpretations were necessary to determine whether the adjustments are significant or not. The coefficients obtained may also be evaluated if the data are adjusted on characteristic straight lines in the Arrhenius graphs for the rate coefficients and in the Van’t Hoff graphs for the adsorption coefficients [17]. 3 Results and discussion The high selectivity dehydration of fructose to HMF catalyzed by the SGC650H acid resin in DMSO proved to be influenced by the catalyst’s concentration, residence time, temperature and the reagent’s initial concentration, among other factors. The main factor seems to be the absence of a porous system. A blank test was carried out to verify if the DMSO solvent presented any catalytical activity, in the batch reactor at 110 °C with a feed of 4.5% (m/m) of fructose without resin. After 2 h of reaction, it did not present any apparent formation of HMF in the HPLC analyses. This fact is in accordance with a published study made at 130 °C [33]. Therefore, it was considered that the product generated was catalyzed mainly by the resin under the experimental conditions applied. 3.1 Reaction temperature effect High yield from HMF was obtained by using fructose as a reagent, SGC650H as catalyst and DMSO as a solvent in the BTR, which virtually reached 100% after 3 h of reaction at 100 °C. The use of the DMSO anhydrous solvent enabled us to keep the water concentration low in the reaction medium, reducing the formation of hydrolysis products and humin. In Fig. 4 , it is observed that the reaction was favored by the rise in temperature, once the increase in HMF yield reveals a faster consumption of the reagent, requiring a shorter reaction time. The same effect was observed in different systems [36–41] which are in accordance with that observed by Kuster [6]; and justifies that the temperature rise effect favoring the reaction, is due to the activation energy of the HMF formation being higher than the HMF consumption. Besides, the enolization rate is higher at elevated temperatures in a way that the acyclical forms and furanose of the fructose are higher. Low temperatures lead to low HMF yield, while elevated temperatures foster the formation of by-products [7]. This fact can be explained because the reaction is sensitive to the temperature, significantly increasing the reaction rate due to the endothermic nature of the fructose dehydration reaction. However, the HMF selectivity decreases due to the formation of humins and soluble polymers. Additionally, longer reaction times increase the water formation, and they consequently accelerate the reaction of levulinic acid formation, as already observed [8,18–21]. In the HMF yield profiles in the BTR, the differences in the concentrations of the samples gotten at the time 0 h of the reaction were noticeable, in which the reaction medium reached the reaction temperature under study. These differences were more evident from the curves at 110 °C, showing that the HMF product was formed during the heating before the reaction’s initial time. Besides, it was possible to realize that its reaction rates in the PBR were higher than in the BTR. The time needed to reach high yield values were shorter, with values above 74% in 20 min at 90 °C, in contrast to the values below 55% at an equivalent time for the batch reactor at 110 °C (Fig. 4). 3.2 Fructose concentration feed effect The use of high concentrations of substrate feed is desirable for economic reasons [6]. However, this increases the possibility of collisions among the reactive compounds, favoring the formation of humins and polymers, thus decreasing selectivity. This effect was observed through the fastest reaction tendency for the tests with the lowest substrate concentrations, in order to demand shorter reaction times to achieve the same yield (Fig. 4). In the experiments with higher fructose feed concentration (13.5% m/m), the HMF formation curve was in an inferior position in relation to the other curves. This fact could be explained due to the increase or appearance of limitations by transport phenomena or the increase in the adsorption of reagents, solvent or products in the catalyst. Furthermore, polymerization and formation of humins is more probable to occur, thus decreasing the HMF selectivity, as observed by [18,19,21,22] and these humins present a color ranging from brown to black, which can be visually verified when comparing the samples [6]. The dry-based catalyst concentration was 450.0 g/L in the PBR and approximately 56.5 g/L in the BTR, therefore (Ccat )PBR/(Ccat )BTR = 8.0 (Table 2). Which means that, under the same temperature conditions and feed concentration, the average residence time needed to reach the same conversion is 8.0 times higher in the batch reactor, while the reaction rate is 8.0 times higher in the continuous reactor. Experimentally, these behaviors were confirmed with variations smaller than 5%. An essential outcome of the catalyst concentration being higher in the continuous reactor (PBR) is the lower probability of occurring parallel or consecutive homogeneous reactions (at the liquid phase), once the residence time in the PBR is shorter to reach the same conversion values. 3.3 Kinetic modeling: integral method Even without the conversion data, it is known that every HMF molecule from the reaction medium is generated from fructose molecule. Thus, the conversion must be equal, if there were no parallel reactions. Alternatively, conversion would be higher than the HMF yield when by-products were generated. The conversion was calculated based on this reaction stoichiometry and considering that there were no secondary reactions from fructose, in a way that the HMF selectivity was admitted as 100% [21,31]. The values of the constants of the reaction rate in relation to the catalyst mass presented in Table 3 correspond to the graphic qualitative analyses obtained from Figs. 4 and 5 : higher k′ for higher reaction temperatures and lower for higher reagent concentrations. The Arrhenius parameters presented in Table 3 were obtained from the rate constants of the reaction in terms of catalyst mass through linear Arrhenius graphs illustrated in Fig. 6 . It is observed that the curves presented in Fig. 6 tend to present an intersection at a specific temperature. This tendency is known as the isokinetic phenomenon of compensation or kinetic compensation effect (KCE), which is confirmed by the Cremer-Constable Diagram (Fig. 7 ) and shows a linear tendency between the values obtained from ln(k0′) and Ea. The variation of the activation energy values observed frequently occurs in heterogeneous catalysis when modifying controlled variables, in this case, the reagent concentration. If the reaction presents the compensation effect, the curves of the Arrhenius diagram for different data sets cross at the same point called isokinetic temperature [23]. In this study, the isokinetic temperature calculated is between 80 and 90 °C. 3.4 Kinetic modeling: iterative method The integral method calculates the kinetic constant at the beginning of the reaction, presuming that the reaction’s temperature is constant; however, in the BTR experiments, this temperature varied during the heating so that the product had already been formed before the time t = 0 h. The iterative method, by optimization, treated the temperature as a variable to simulate the concentration of the reagent and calculated the Arrhenius parameters for the pseudo-first-order reaction, which values are presented in Table 4 . Once again, a variation in the linear activation energy values for different feed concentrations was observed, so that a compensation effect of the ln(k0′) pre-exponential term occurs, as presented in the Cremer-Constable graph (Fig. 7). Among the several probable causes for the compensation effect, we can mention the reaction rates on the catalyst surfaces or active sites varying in a different way since the mechanism involves the formation of intermediates; variation of the reagent’s concentration, which is not the same as fed; the existence of parallel reactions so that the same reaction occurs at different sites of the catalyst, or between different sites of the same molecule [24–26]. The results for the activation energy obtained in this study are similar to those obtained by Lee & Wu (67.5 and 80.05 kJ/mol) with sulfonic ionic liquid functionalized mesoporous silica [31]. However, they were smaller than the ones obtained by Moreau et al. [27,28], which is 141 kJ/mol for the reaction catalyzed by H-mordenite zeolite in the biphasic solvent water-MIBK, and 143 kJ/mol for the ionic liquid HMIM+Cl− and ln(k0′) = 39. The apparent activation energy of the order of 53 kJ/mol was reported using mesoporous zirconium phosphate catalysts in DMSO, presenting higher reaction rates at a specific temperature [21]. As the data in these study presents a compensation effect (KCE), any comparison of the parameters obtained from catalysts used in different systems is impaired. Moreover both Arrhenius parameters are needed for comparisons among different studies. The Ea and ln(k0′) data presented by Moureu et al. [28] are also aligned in the Cremer-Constable Diagram with the data obtained in this study, which may indicate a possible similarity regarding reaction mechanisms. One possible explanation for this similarity would be the reactivity difference among isomeric species of fructose which vary with temperature [14] and may vary with fructose concentration. 3.5 LHHW kinetic model The data from the experiments with the BTR obtained through the integral method allowed us to plot the initial reaction rate graph according to the reagent’s initial concentration (Fig. 8 ). From the graph, it was possible to conclude that the desorption of the product is not the limiting stage, as it did not present independent CF0 profiles; however, it could not be deduced if the adsorption or the reaction on the surface was the rate-limiting step, and therefore both hypotheses were tested. Evaluating several models using both hypotheses, we noticed that the Van’t Hoff graphs obtained incoherent signals for angular coefficients, allowing us to conclude that no model used was correct. For this reason, it was concluded that the mechanism of the fructose dehydration reaction is much complicated. A more detailed study should be carried out in the future to obtain a rate law which applies to any temperature condition and substrate concentration.The mechanisms proposed in the literature [14,29,30] showed that the reaction occurs with the formation of intermediates so that the rate law might be obtained by using the pseudo-stationary state phase approach (HEPE). However, the occurrence of the compensation effect (KCE) showed previously could indicate the existence of parallel processes which would hamper the development of a representative kinetic model for the reaction mechanism. Studies using RMN [14,29], revealed not only the existence of intermediates in the HMF formation reaction from fructose using DMSO as a solvent but also showed the presence of five isomeric species of fructose. The quantity of them varies according to the temperature, and include an open chain form, α and β pyranoses, α and β furanoses. Among the later, β-d-fructofuranose shows the higher concentration in reaction media. More recently, some insights over the role of DMSO in fructose dehydration in the presence of Brönsted acid arise from new findings based on theoretical calculations [35]. Besides the tautomeric forms of fructose, DMSO molecules also could be protonated and has activity in the first and third dehydration steps [35]. This way, it is possible that both phenomena are responsible for the KCE observed. Therefore, a representative model may take into account the balance between the reactivity of different isomers of fructose and the role played by the catalyst and DMSO as co-catalyst in the different steps of the reaction. 4 Conclusion The use of fructose as a reagent, SGC650H (gel-type strongly acidic resin) as catalyst and DMSO as solvent allowed for the obtaining of high HMF selectivity and yield. It was observed that the behavior of the fructose dehydration reaction for the formation of HMF is favored by increase in temperature, reduction in feed substrate concentrations and when a continuous reactor (PBR) was used instead of a batch reactor (BTR). The reaction’s rate constants obtained through the integral method for the continuous packed bed reactor (PBR) were higher than the ones for the batch reactor (BTR). This fact can partially be explained by the calculation method applied, which determines the rate constant at the reaction’s initial stage. Although it was possible to obtain important conclusions from the BTR results, the PBR reactor proved to be more adequate for the kinetic study of heterogeneous catalysts for this system. Since the time needed to reach a given conversion is shorter in the PBR than in the BTR, less interference of series or parallel homogeneous reactions is expected. The Arrhenius parameters calculated for different concentrations of fructose presented a characteristic variation known as kinetic compensation effect (KCE). This variation of the parameters obtained indicated that the calculated values are apparent and that the pseudo-first-order pseudo-homogeneous kinetic model adopted is insufficient to describe the reaction, as there would be other relevant factors that should be considered in the rate law. By applying the rate-limiting step (RLS) method and considering the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LHHW) approach with the experimental data obtained in the BTR, it was not possible to define a feasible model with the data available. Therefore, a kinetic model with significant values for the heterogeneous reaction through the methodology applied, was not obtained. As a mechanism for the heterogeneous catalytic reaction could not be determined, another method, i.e, the pseudo-stationary phase hypothesis (HEPE) could be applied in the future to obtain the rate law when considering series reactions. This model should regard the existence of previously identified intermediates species and the reactions that occurs in parallel, examining the existence of fructose isomers, the chemical balance among them and the interference of DMSO as co-catalyst. coredata.dc:description: 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furfural (HMF) is an important furanic compound that can be obtained from renewable raw materials. HMF has wide application in the industry, acting as an intermediate in the production of fine chemicals, polymer, biofuels, and pharmaceuticals. In this research, HMF was obtained from the catalytic fructose dehydration. Purolite® SGC650H, a gel-type strongly acidic resin, was applied as a catalyst using dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) as a solvent. All experiments were carried out in a batch reactor (BTR) and a continuous packed bed reactor (PBR). The reactor performance data showed that increase in temperature resulted in higher HMF yield. In contrast, the higher the fructose concentration, the lower the HMF conversion. The HMF production rates in the PBR were higher because of the concentration of the catalyst. The rate constants were calculated by means of a pseudo-first-order reaction model, and the Arrhenius kinetic parameters obtained changed with regards to the reactants concentrations. The kinetic parameters displayed linear correlation in the Cremer-Constable diagram, which means that the system was under a kinetic compensation effect (KCE); therefore, the model was not suitable to represent the reaction. Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LHHW) models for rate equation were also tested. However all of them failed to adjust to the data, and thus a rate law was not determined. Due to the observed KCE, it was believed that there is at least a set of parallel dehydration reactions initiated from the different fructose isomers which has an influence on kinetic parameters.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of HMF from fructose using Purolite® strong acid catalyst: Comparison between BTR and PBR reactor type for kinetics data acquisition
